217     carpet and/or moss
0000    >$<
-1
6
1       Somewhere nearby is Colossal Cave, where others have found fortunes in
1       treasure and gold, though it is rumored that some who enter are never
1       seen again.  Magic is said to work in the cave.  I will be your eyes
1       and hands.  Direct me with natural English commands and I will tell
1       you where you are and describe what is happening around you.  My
1       normal language is Fnordish, so if I don't always understand what
1       you tell me, be patient and try to say the same thing some other way.
1       - - - -
1       (If this is your first trip to ADVENTURE-Land, you should type
1       "HELP" to get some general instructions.)
1       Good Luck!
1       - - - -
2       A little dwarf with a big knife blocks your way.
3       A little dwarf just walked around a corner, saw you, threw a little
3       axe at you which missed, cursed, and ran away.
4       There is a threatening little dwarf in the room with you!
5       One sharp nasty knife is thrown at you!
6       None of them hit you!
7       One of them gets you!
8       A hollow voice says "Plugh".
9       There is no way to go that direction.
10      I am unsure how you are facing.  Use compass points or nearby objects.
11      I don't know in from out here.  Use compass points or name something
11      in the general direction you want to go.
12      I don't know how to apply that word here.
13      I don't understand that!
14      I'm game.  Would you care to explain how?
15      Sorry, but I am not allowed to give more detail.  I will repeat the
15      long description of your location.
16      It is now pitch dark.  If you proceed you will likely fall into a pit.
17      If you prefer, simply type "W" rather than "West".
18      Are you trying to catch the bird?
19      If you want to snatch the birdy's bod,
19      You'd better hide that nasty rod.
20      Are you trying to somehow deal with the snake?
21      That nasty snake means to stay;
21      You'll need a friend's help to chase her away.
22      Do you really want to quit now?
23      You fell into a pit and broke every bone in your body!
24      You are already carrying it!
25      You can't be serious!
26      The bird was unafraid when you entered, but as you approach it becomes
26      disturbed and you cannot catch it.
27      You can catch the bird, but you cannot carry it.
28      There is nothing here with a lock!
29      You aren't carrying it!
30      The little bird attacks the green snake, and in an astounding flurry
30      drives the snake away.
31      You have no keys!
32      It has no lock.
33      I don't know how to lock or unlock such a thing.
34      It was already locked.
35      Are you kidding?  You'd break every tooth in your mouth!
36      The label on the bag reads: "Mix with care.  Property of
36      Witt Construction Company".
37      It was already unlocked.
38      You have no source of light.
39      Your lamp is now on.
40      Your lamp is now off.
41      There is no way to get past the bear to unlock the chain, which is
41      probably just as well.
42      Nothing happens.
43      Where?
44      There is nothing here to attack.
45      The little bird is now dead.  Its body disappears.
46      Attacking the snake both doesn't work and is very dangerous.
47      You killed a little dwarf.
48      You attack a little dwarf, but he dodges out of the way.
49      With what?  Your bare hands?
50      Good try, but that is an old worn-out magic word.
51      Welcome.    In ADVENTURE you are invited to exercise your intelligence
51      and imagination in the attempt to explore and master Colossal Cave and
51      its environs.
51      >$<
51      You can "move" from place to place by typing in various motion  verbs,
51      such as FOREST, BUILDING, DOWNSTREAM, ENTER, EAST, WEST, NORTH, SOUTH,
51      UP,  or  DOWN.   As you move from place to place, I will describe your
51      surroundings.  The first time you enter a place, I'll give you a  full
51      description,  but,  just to move things along, I'll give you a shorter
51      description when (if) you return.
51      >$<
51      To speed the game you can sometimes move long distances with a  single
51      word.  For example, "BUILDING" (or "B", for short) usually gets you to
51      the  building  from anywhere above ground except when lost or near the
51      castle.  Also, note that cave passages turn a lot, and that leaving  a
51      room to the north does not guarantee entering the next from the south.
51      You'd best make yourself a map as you go along.
51      >$<
51      I  know  about a number of special objects, like a BLACK ROD hidden in
51      the cave.  These objects can be manipulated using action words that  I
51      know.   Examples of action verbs are TAKE, DROP, OPEN, DRINK, READ and
51      so forth.  To manipulate objects, type normal  declarative  sentences.
51      For example, if you wanted to pick up the black rod and insert it into
51      a sack you could type:
51      >$<
51          TAKE BLACK ROD AND PUT IT INTO THE SACK
51          PICK UP SACK AND CLOSE IT
51      >$<
51      Use  of  some  objects  may  have  side effects; for instance, the ROD
51      scares the BIRD.  Usually people trying unsuccessfully  to  manipulate
51      an  object are attempting something beyond their (or my!) capabilities
51      and should try a completely different tack.
51      >$<
51      As you progress through the  cave,  you  may  find  objects  of  value
51      (treasures).  Each treasure has a point value associated with it.  Its
51      value is roughly proportional to the degree of difficulty of obtaining
51      it.    To get full credit for a treasure, you must have left it safely
51      in the building, though you get partial credit just for  locating  it.
51      Note  that  leaving treasures *safely* in the building may be trickier
51      than you think!
51      >$<
51      You lose points for getting killed, or for asking  for  hints,  though
51      the  former  costs  you more.  There are also points based on how much
51      (if any) of the cave you've managed to explore; in  particular,  there
51      is  a  large bonus just for getting in (to distinguish the dilletantes
51      from the rest of the pack), and there  are  other  ways  to  determine
51      whether you've been through some of the more harrowing sections.
51      >$<
51      If you think you've found all the treasures, just keep exploring for a
51      while.    If  nothing  interesting happens, you haven't found them all
51      yet.  If something interesting *DOES* happen, it means you're  getting
51      a  bonus  and  have  an  opportunity to garner many more points in the
51      Master's Section.  I may occasionally offer hints if you  seem  to  be
51      having  trouble.    If I do, I'll warn you in advance how much it will
51      affect your score to accept the hints.
51      >$<
51      A word about my understanding of English -- I will try very hard to do
51      whatever you say, but here  are  a  few  suggestions.    To  scarf  up
51      everything movable at a given location, say 'TAKE EVERYTHING' or 'TAKE
51      ALL'.    Some  objects may be differentiated only by some attribute or
51      other.  For example, if you  were  holding  both  a  red  and  a  blue
51      frammitz,  you  would  have to distinguish between them by typing 'RED
51      FRAMMITZ' or 'BLUE FRAMMITZ' so that I'll know  which  one  you  mean.
51      Also,  you  can  specify several actions or objects by using commas or
51      'AND', as 'TAKE ABC,DEF AND XYZ AND BURN WITCH'.
51      >$<
51      The following commands will help you to play the game:
51      >$<
51      BRIEF           To save paper, you may type the command "BRIEF", which
51                      tells me never to repeat the  full  description  of  a
51                      place unless you explicitly ask me to.
51      >$<
51      DIAGNOSE        In  addition  to getting yourself killed, you can also
51                      be wounded or injured in  various  (non-lethal)  ways.
51                      If  you get burnt, poisoned, electrocuted or whatever,
51                      you can check on  your  current  state  of  health  by
51                      typing 'HEALTH' or 'DIAGNOSE'.  Note that recuperation
51                      takes place faster outside in the fresh air!
51      >$<
51      EXAMINE         A  general verb for inspecting objects, e.g., "EXAMINE
51                      FRAMMITZ".  Will often give useful  information  about
51                      the specified object.  More specific operations can be
51                      performed with the verb "LOOK", described below.
51      >$<
51      GRIPE           If  you  think  you have run into a program bug, or if
51                      you have any ideas for extensions to  the  cave,  type
51                      "GRIPE"  or  "REPORT" and then enter as long a message
51                      as you like.  This will be immediately transmitted  to
51                      the Wizard, who will try to reply within a day or two.
51      >$<
51      HOURS           To  see  what  hours  the  cave  is normally open, say
51                      "HOURS".
51      >$<
51      INVENTORY, I    Lists what you are currently carrying.
51      >$<
51      LOOK, L         Reprints the detailed description of  where  you  are.
51                      You  can  also  "LOOK  IN",  "LOOK  AT"  or "LOOK FOR"
51                      appropriate objects.
51      >$<
51      QUIT            To end your adventure immediately.
51      >$<
51      PAUSE           To  suspend  your adventure such that you can continue
51                      later, say "SUSPEND" (or "PAUSE" or "SAVE").  When you
51                      pause in mid-game, a small disk file, named by you, is
51                      created  which  holds  all  the  variable  information
51                      pertinent  to  your game.  Prudent players should save
51                      their games  prior  to  attempting  new  or  dangerous
51                      challenges.
51      >$<
51      RESUME          A  suspended  game  can  be resumed by beginning a new
51                      game and then typing "RESUME".
51      >$<
51      SCORE, TURNS    Tells you how well you're doing.
51      >$<
51      TERSE           Experienced  players  may  suppress  *all*   long-form
51                      descriptions  by  typing  "TERSE".   You can return to
51                      normal  description  mode  by  typing   "UNBRIEF"   or
51                      "UNTERSE".
51      >$<
51      TREASURE(S)     You  may  manipulate  nearby treasures as a group with
51                      the class  word  "TREASURES"  ("PRIZES",  "VALUABLES",
51                      "T").
51      >$<
51      Comments        If you are playing on a hard-copy terminal and wish to
51                      type  comments,  simply type a semi-colon (";") at any
51                      point on the input line.  Everything you type in after
51                      the semicolon is ignored by the parser.
51      >$<
51      Best Game       To encourage competition amongst the hackers, a  minor
51                      new  feature  has been added to the game.  At startup,
51                      the best game since some base date will be  displayed.
51                      "Best  game"  is  that  game having the combination of
51                      highest score and lowest number of turns.  A new  game
51                      having  a  score  higher  than  the  current best game
51                      always becomes the new best game.  A new game having a
51                      score equal to the current best  game  but  played  in
51                      fewer turns becomes the new best game.
51      >$<
51      Adventurers interested in the history and development of Colossal Cave
51      and  environs  should  find  the  contents  of  the  safe  of especial
51      interest.
51      >$<
51      Those interested in obtaining the latest releases of this game  should
51      contact:
51      >$<
51          David E. Long
51          GSB Computing Services
51          University of Chicago
51          1101 E 58th Street
51          Chicago IL 60637
51              Phone: 312/753-0860.
51      >$<
51      Finally,   adventurers   should  regularly  check  the  billboard  for
51      announcements of current interest.
51      >$<
51                         Copyright (C) 1980 David E. Long
51      >$<
52      It misses!
53      It gets you!
54      Ok
55      You can't unlock the keys.
56      You have crawled around in some little holes and wound up back in the
56      main passage.
57      I don't know where the cave is, but hereabouts no stream can run on
57      the surface for long.  I would try the stream.
58      I need more detailed instructions to do that.
59      I can only tell you what you see as you move about and manipulate
59      things.  I cannot tell you where remote things are.
60      I can't make any sense out of that.
61      What?
62      Are you trying to get into the cave?
63      The grate is set in solid rock;
63      You'll need some keys to pick that lock.
64      The trees of the forest are large hardwood oak and maple, with an
64      occasional grove of pine or spruce.  There is quite a bit of under-
64      growth, largely birch and ash saplings plus nondescript bushes of
64      various sorts.  This time of year visibility is quite restricted by
64      all the leaves, but travel is quite easy if you detour around the
64      spruce and berry bushes.
65      Welcome to ADVENTURE!!  Would you like instructions?
66      Digging without a shovel is quite impractical.  Even with a shovel
66      progress is unlikely.
67      Blasting requires dynamite.
68      I'm as confused as you are.
69      Mist is a white vapor, usually water, seen from time to time in
69      caverns.  It can be found anywhere but is frequently a sign of a deep
69      pit leading down to water.
70      Your feet are now wet.
71      I think I just lost my appetite.
72      Thank you, it was delicious!
73      You have taken a drink from the clear water.  The water tastes
73      strongly of minerals, but is not unpleasant.  It is extremely cold.
74      The bottle is now empty.
75      Rubbing the electric lamp is not particularly rewarding.  Anyway,
75      nothing exciting happens.
76      Peculiar.  Nothing unexpected happens.
77      Your bottle is empty and the ground is wet.
78      The ground here is not suitable for digging.
79      Watch it!
80      Which way?
81      Oh dear, you seem to have gotten yourself killed.  I might be able to
81      help you out, but I've never really done this before.  Do you want me
81      to try to reincarnate you?
82      All right.  But don't blame me if something goes wr......
82      *                    --- POOF!! ---                    *
82      You are engulfed in a cloud of orange smoke.  Coughing and gasping,
82      you emerge from the smoke and find....
83      You clumsy oaf, you've done it again!  I don't know how long I can
83      keep this up.  Do you want me to try reincarnating you again?
84      Okay, now where did I put my orange smoke?....  >POOF!<
84      Everything disappears in a dense cloud of orange smoke.
85      Now you've really done it!  I'm out of orange smoke!  You don't expect
85      me to do a decent reincarnation without any orange smoke, do you?
86      Okay, if you're so smart, do it yourself!  I'm leaving!
90      >>> Messages 81 thru 90 are reserved for "Obituaries". <<<
91      Sorry, but I no longer seem to remember how it was you got here.
92      It's too heavy.  You'll have to drop something first.
93      You can't go through a locked steel grate!
94      I believe what you want is right here with you.
95      You don't fit through a two-inch slit!
96      I respectfully suggest you go across the bridge instead of jumping.
97      There is no way across the fissure.
98      You're not carrying anything.
99      You are currently holding the following:
100     It's not hungry (it's merely pinin' for the fjords).  Besides, you
100     have no bird seed.
101     The snake has now devoured your bird.
102     There's nothing here it wants to eat (except perhaps you).
103     You fool, dwarves eat only coal!  Now you've made him *REALLY* mad!!
104     Your cask is empty and the ground is soaked.
105     You aren't carrying them!
106     I don't need to, thank you.
107     The ground is wet and the air is smelly.
108     Your lamp is now on, but the glare from the walls is absolutely
108     blinding.  If you proceed you are likely to fall into a pit.
109     The vines are extremely tough and deeply rooted into the cliff wall.
109     And they wouldn't be good for much anyway.
110     Don't be ridiculous!
111     The door is extremely rusty and refuses to open.
112     The plant indignantly shakes dry its leaves and asks, "Water?"
113     The hinges are quite thoroughly rusted now and won't budge.
114     The oil has freed up the hinges so that the door will now move,
114     although it requires some effort.
115     The plant has exceptionally deep roots and cannot be pulled free.
116     The dwarves' knives vanish as they strike the walls of the cave.
117     Something you're carrying won't fit through the tunnel with you.
117     You'd best take inventory and drop something.
118     You can't fit this five-foot clam through that little passage!
119     You can't fit this five-foot oyster through that little passage!
120     I advise you to put down the clam before opening it.  >Strain!<
121     I advise you to put down the oyster before opening it.  >Wrench!<
122     You don't have anything strong enough to open the clam.
123     You don't have anything strong enough to open the oyster.
124     A glistening pearl falls out of the clam and rolls away.  Goodness,
124     this must really be an oyster.  (I never was very good at identifying
124     bivalves.)  Whatever it is, it has now snapped shut again.
125     The oyster creaks open, revealing nothing but oyster inside.  It
125     promptly snaps shut again.
126     You have crawled around in some little holes and found your way
126     blocked by a recent cave-in.  You are now back in the main passage.
127     There are faint rustling noises from the darkness behind you.
128     Out from the shadows behind you pounces a bearded pirate!  "Har, har,"
128     he chortles, "I'll just take all this booty and hide it away with me
128     chest deep in the maze!"  He snatches your treasure and vanishes into
128     the gloom.
129     A sepulchral voice reverberating through the cave, says, "Cave closing
129     soon.  All adventurers exit immediately through Main Office."
130     A mysterious recorded voice groans into life and announces:
130        "This exit is closed.  Please leave via Main Office."
131     It looks as though you're dead.  Well, seeing as how it's so close to
131     closing time anyway, I think we'll just call it a day.
132     The sepulchral voice entones, "The cave is now closed."  As the echoes
132     fade, there is a blinding flash of light (and a small puff of orange
132     smoke). . . .    As your eyes refocus, you look around and find...
133     There is a loud explosion, and a twenty-foot hole appears in the far
133     wall, burying the dwarves in the rubble.  You march through the hole
133     and find yourself in the Main Office, where a cheering band of
133     friendly elves carry the conquering adventurer off into the sunset.
134     There is a loud explosion, and a twenty-foot hole appears in the far
134     wall, burying the snakes in the rubble.  A river of molten lava pours
134     in through the hole, destroying everything in its path, including you!
135     There is a loud explosion, and you are suddenly splashed across the
135     walls of the room.
136     The resulting ruckus has awakened the dwarves.  There are now several
136     threatening little dwarves in the room with you!  Most of them throw
136     knives at you!  All of them get you!
137     Oh, leave the poor unhappy bird alone.
138     I daresay whatever you want is around here somewhere.
139     I'm not sure what you mean by "Stop".  Use "Quit" if you want to give
139     up.
140     You can't get there from here.
141     You are being followed by a very large, tame bear.
142                *** THE HISTORY OF ADVENTURE (ABRIDGED) ***
142                            By:  W. I. Zerd, F.R.C.W.
142     >$<
142     ADVENTURE was originally developed by William Crowther, and later
142     substantially rewritten and expanded by Don Woods at Stanford Univ.
142     According to legend, Crowther's original version was modelled on an
142     a real cavern, called Colossal Cave, which is a part of Kentucky's
142     Mammoth Caverns.  That version of the game included the main maze
142     and a portion of the third-level (Complex Junction - Bedquilt -
142     Swiss Cheese rooms, etc.), but not much more.
142     >$<
142     Don Woods and some others at Stanford later rewrote portions of
142     the original program, and greatly expanded the cave.  That version
142     of the game is recognizable by the maximum score of 350 points.
142     >$<
142     The latest additions were done throughout 1978-80 by David Long
142     at the University of Chicago, Graduate School of Business.
142     Long's additions include the seaside entrance and all of
142     the cave on the "far side" of Lost River (Rainbow Rm - Crystal
142     Palace - Blue Grotto - Rotunda - beyond Joshua's wall, etc., etc.).
142     The surface has also been greatly increased to include a much
142     more varied landscape containing swamp, marsh, seashore and
142     meadowland areas.  Most recent additions include the great Castle of
142     Aldor, the Elephants' Burial Ground, Leprechaun Rock and more.
142     The current cave is more than double the size of the Woods model,
142     and moreover the puzzles and treasures are somewhat more "dense",
142     (and more difficult!) in the current version.  During the expansion
142     process, the code was almost entirely rewritten to permit more
142     generalized handling of objects and to interpret a more complex
142     natural English syntax.
142     >$<
142     Except for a couple of trivial subroutines (to get user-ID's for
142     logging purposes), ADVENTURE is written entirely in FORTRAN.  This
142     not because Crowther/Woods/Long love FORTRAN, but because it is
142     almost infinitely portable.  There were indeed moments when it took
142     great strength to withstand the temptation to whip out some character
142     handling routine in MACRO, instead of the furshlugginer compiler.
142     For example, there is an excellent rival game to Adventure, called
142     DUNGEON, developed at M.I.T., which is totally non-portable since
142     it is coded in an obscure variant of two initially obscure compilers,
142     and can only be transported in executable form between DEC-10's
142     and 20's.
142     >$<
142     Thanks are owed to Roger Matus and David Feldman, both of U. of C.,
142     for several suggestions, including the Rainbow Room, the telephone
142     booth and the fearsome Wumpus.  Further thanks go to J. R. Carlson,
142     Bob Silverman and John Rager for many debugging suggestions.
142     Most thanks (and apologies) go to Thomas Malory, Charles Dodgson,
142     the Grimm Brothers, Dante, Homer, Frank Baum and especially Anon.,
142     the real authors of ADVENTURE.
142     >$<
142            Copyright (C) 1978, 1979, 1980, David E. Long
143     Do you indeed wish to quit now?
144     There is nothing here with which to fill the vase.
145     The sudden change in temperature has delicately shattered the vase.
146     It is beyond your power to do that.
147     I don't know how.
148     It is too far up for you to reach.
149     You killed a little dwarf.  The body vanishes in a cloud of greasy
149     black smoke.
150     The shell is very strong and is impervious to attack.
151     What's the matter, can't you read?  Now you'd best start over.
152     The axe bounces harmlessly off the dragon's thick scales.
153     The dragon looks rather nasty.  You'd best not try to get by.
154     The little bird attacks the green dragon, and in an astounding flurry
154     gets burnt to a cinder.  The ashes blow away.
155     On what?
156     Okay, from now on I'll only describe a place in full the first time
156     you come to it.  To get the full description, say "LOOK".
157     Trolls are close relatives with the rocks and have skin as tough as
157     that of a rhinoceros.  The troll fends off your blows effortlessly.
158     The troll deftly catches the axe, examines it carefully, and tosses it
158     back, declaring, "Good workmanship, but it's not valuable enough."
159     The troll catches your treasure and scurries away out of sight.
160     The troll refuses to let you cross.
161     There is no longer any way across the chasm.
162     Just as you reach the other side, the bridge buckles beneath the
162     weight of the bear, which was still following you around.  You
162     scrabble desperately for support, but as the bridge collapses you
162     stumble back and fall into the chasm.
163     The bear lumbers toward the troll, who lets out a startled shriek and
163     scurries away.  The bear soon gives up the pursuit and wanders back.
164     The axe misses and lands near the bear where you can't get at it.
165     With what?  Your bare hands?  Against *HIS* bear hands??
166     The bear is confused; he only wants to be your friend.
167     For crying out loud, the poor thing is already dead!
168     The bear eagerly licks up the honeycomb, after which he seems to calm
168     down considerably and even becomes rather friendly.
169     The bear is still chained to the wall.
170     The chain is still locked.

171     into it on this side.  The ravine wall is extremely steep, however.
172     How?  Through solid rock?
173     There is nothing here to which the chain can be locked.
174     There is nothing here to eat.

183     machine in the maze.  Bring some coins with you.

186     With that, he vanishes into the gloom.

189     best start wrapping this up.

265     seemingly solid rock wall crumbles away, revealing another room just
265     beyond.  The wall was most likely worn thin by an ancient watercourse
265     which dried up just before completely wearing away the rock.

276     and then one more (!!), and looks at you sleepily.  He had been
276     dreaming of a late snack.  If you don't act quickly, you'll
276     be a *late* adventurer!

278     interested.

280     Setting yourself adrift in the boat with no way to propel it would

318     The bridge shakes as you cross.  Large hunks of clay and rock near
318     the edge break off and hurtle far down into the chasm.  Several of
318     the cracks on the bridge surface widen perceptibly.
319     The load is too much for the bridge!  With a roar, the entire
319     structure gives way, plunging you headlong into the raging river at
319     the bottom of the chasm and scattering all your holdings.  As the
319     icy waters close over your head, you flail and thrash with all your
319     might, and with your last ounce of strength pull yourself onto the
319     south bank of the river.

324     here with your light on.

325     you turn, a creature the size of a large dog disappears into
325     some bushes.

363     Brushing the dust from one of the larger rocks reveals some carved
363     characters.

365     The safe door smoothly swings open.

367     The safe's door clicks shut.
368     This is a combination safe.  The keys won't help.
369     I certainly can't read in this light.
370     The poster has a picture of a thin man with a long white beard.
370     He is wearing a high pointed cap embroidered with strange symbols,
370     and he is pointing a finger at you.  Below the picture are the words:
370     >$<
370     !--------------------------------------------------------------------!
370     ! "I want you!--To report all good ideas for extensions to this game !
370     ! to me without delay.  Remember: ask not what ADVENTURE can do to   !
370     ! you; ask what you can do for ADVENTURE."                           !
370     !                           -  -  -                                  !
370     ! >>>A public service of the John-Dillinger-Died-for-You Society<<<  !
370     !--------------------------------------------------------------------!
371     "Click."
372     In the rock is carved the inscription:
372     >$<
372           +------------------------------------------------+
372           !                In Memoriam:                    !
372           !  John Dillinger, Liberator of the Little Man.  !
372           !               Died: 7-22-34.                   !
372           +------------------------------------------------+
373     All the food needed was a bit of spicing up: it smells delicious!
374     Ok, I'll give you the full description whenever you enter a room
374     for the first time.

376     That's not strong enough to open the clam.
377     That's not strong enough to open the oyster.
378     The top of the bottle is too small.  You can't get it in.
379     There is only a small hole in one end of the cask.  You can't force
379     anything solid through the hole.
380     >>> Messages 381 thru 389 are reserved for "Diagnoses". <<<
381     You are a bit off top form, but nothing to worry about.
382     You are weaker than usual.  Better avoid fights.
383     You really ought to take a break.  You're in tough shape.
384     You are on the edge of collapse.  Lots of sun and fresh air will
384     speed your recovery.
385     Your strength is nearly gone.  Only a miracle can save you now.
386     ** Reserved **
387     ** Reserved **
388     ** Reserved **
389     ** Reserved **
390     >>> Messages 391 thru 399 are reserved for Radium Poisoning. <<<
391     Is it hot in here?  You are flushed and sweating.
392     You are feeling definitely peculiar, weak....
393     You're dizzy, nauseous.  You can barely stand.
394     You are really ill.  If you don't find an antidote soon, it's
394     curtains.
395     You are a walking wound.  You are very weak.  You'd better find out
395     what's wrong before it's too late.
396     Sheeesh!  What a mess!  Your hair has fallen out and your skin is
396     covered with blisters.  And not an aspirin in sight!
397     Well, you tried, but your strength is gone.  The agony is finally
397     over.
398     ** Reserved **
399     ** Reserved **
400     The ledge is too steep for the bear, who refuses to follow.
401     The path in that direction is too steep.  You can't proceed.
402     You have stumbled blindly through the trackless muck.
403     On the back of the billboard is a scrawled note:
403     >$<
403              B E   A L E R T !!    The world needs more lerts.
404     As the grey powder mixes with the bubbling quicksand, the whole
404     mixture gradually thickens to a rocklike hardness.
405     The grey powder is too fine to pick up.
406     You are standing in a knee-deep hole in the bat guano.
407     You are up to your hips in bat guano.
408     You've got bat turds hanging off your ears, wimp!  This isn't
408     getting you anywhere.  Best try somewhere else.
409     You've dug yourself into a three foot hole in the sand.
410     You're up to your waist in sand.
411     You're in a deep pit in the sand.
412     You have unearthed a delicate, multi-hued conch.
413     You can't burn that!
414     It's already burning!
415     You have nothing to light it with!
416     The match flares into flame.
417     You already have a lit match.
418     You have no more matches.
419     The axe is too small to do much good.  The thorns cut your arm.
420     Your elfin sword makes short work of the brambles.  After a few
420     minutes work, you hack a large hole through the tangle.
421     The axe disappears into the thicket.  You can't reach it.
422     The bramble bush sucks up the water and grows even thicker.
423     The dry brambles immediately catch fire and disappear in a roar
423     of flame.
424     You can't reach it.
425     I'm afraid it's a little late for that.
426     As you place the rose into the vase, the rose opens in full bloom,
426     revealing a sachet of rare perfume inside.
427     The following are being removed:
428     <Grunt!>  <Oy-Vey!>  Although the boulder moves a fraction of an inch,
428     it is too heavy for you to roll away.
429     Are you trying to get past the boulder?
430     You're just too tired to move that rock;
430     A good *hot* meal would help a lot.
431     Zam!  What a meal!  Now we're ready for anything!
432     As you approach the rock, an indistinct muttering sound arises from
432     the general area of the rock.  The only word you can hear clearly
432     is "Fnord!"
433     As you approach the rock, the little man suddenly notices your
433     shamrock.  "Well, well," says he, "you may be able to see me now,
433     but you'll never get by this place until you have vanquished one
433     much larger than I!  Fnord!"
434     As you approach the rock, the leprechaun (for indeed that is what he
434     is) notices your shamrock *and* your ring, and with a muttered curse,
434     disappears.
435     Donning the shamrock makes you aware of something you hadn't
435     noticed before....
436     Loose tobacco won't burn.
437     You can't light an empty pipe!
438     Fat chance.
439     No way!
440     Get serious, you bozo!
441     The leaflet reads:
441     >$<
441     Notice: Stairway blocked until further notice.  Upper quarters
441     of castle still under renovation.  -- Haf Witt, Foreman.
442     Through a solid wall?  Sounds pretty tricky to me...
443     Eat flowers?  Only health nuts and left-wingers do that!
444     There is an ominous rustling behind you in some nearby underbrush.
445     From a dark corner of the room a pair of feral eyes glitter
445     brightly, and then vanish silently.
446     A faint sound as of rapid breathing and a fetid stink fills the
446     air for a moment, and then, just as mysteriously as it began, it
446     vanishes.
447     [** UNUSED -- BUG **]
448     Parting the vines reveals a dim recess in the cliff wall.
449     Attacking a creature with 73 feet and hair on its teeth would
449     not be the smartest thing in the world.
450     The axe has no effect on the big bug's armor-like exoskeleton.
451     You couldn't leave well enough alone, could you?
452     You have snatched the centipede's very own security blanket!
453     The food tastes bland, but is not unpalatable.
454     The face of the card bears the embossed legend:
454     >$<

454            !   M E R K I N   E X P R E S S   C A R D  !
454            !                                          !
454            !   (Aren't *YOU* proud to be a Merkin?)   !
454            --------------------------------------------
454     >$<
454     The back of the card is blank, except for a wide, dark-brown stripe.
455     The door is locked.
456     From behind the door there is a whirring sound and the card is
456     sucked from your hand.  A moment later, the great oaken door
456     swings open.
457     The liquid reacts oddly with the black substance covering the
457     statue of the bird.  After a few moments, the black coating
457     dissolves completely, revealing a statue of solid gold encrusted
457     with priceless gems of every description!
458     The door has no keyhole!
459     You are obviously attempting to intrude into a section of the castle
459     in which you have no business.  Faster than you can spit, a
459     trapdoor springs open beneath you, catapulting you into a deep
459     pit at the bottom of which a number of sharp, upright spikes
459     have been affixed.
460     Whoops, it's pitsville again!
461     As soon as you press the last tile, the great steel door slowly
461     swings open with an eerie silence.
462     Done.
463     The lamp is hardwired into the wall above the door.  You can't
463     get at it.
464     From somewhere behind you there is a faint chuckling, but
464     nothing else happens.
465     The thin black coating on the statue goes up in a flash, revealing
465     a statue of solid gold encrusted with priceless gems of every
465     description!
466     "North" is too ambiguous here: you can 'climb' the staircase,
466     or enter one of the N/S hallways on either side of the stairs
466     by typing 'NE' or 'NW'.
467     You are wearing:
468     Ahh, stroke them ivories!   Play it, Sam.
469     The document is written in an undecipherable script.  However,
469     it bears the official seal of the Orcan government.
470     You have no way of manipulating the winch.
471     The iron bar, evidently the winch handle, slips easily into the
471     winch mechanism.
472     The ancient coat-of-arms of the family of Aldor consists of a gold
472     fiddle-dee-dee with bronze oak leaf cluster.  Stemming from the
472     cluster are three brass spheres, under which is the family motto
472     (obviously in Latin): "IN HOC TU OFFEN".
473     The silk sheeting is tightly folded and is attached to the
473     knapsack by numerous strong cords.  You can't remove it.
474     The door slams shut as soon as you hit the button, followed by
474     the sound of the engine revving up.  After many minutes of noise
474     and vibration, the engine falls silent and the door slides open.
475     Rattle, roar, shake, etc....
476     The paper is a worthless deed to a defunct silver mine.
477     The paper is a valuable deed to a reclaimed silver mine.
478     The ledge drops off into a sheer cliff.  You can't climb down.
479     The door is tightly shut.  There is no apparent way to open it.
480     The door is locked on the outside (garden side) with a heavy
480     wooden bar.
481     The garden door is now open.
482     The garden door is now locked.
483     The bar is too heavy to carry.
484     A wimp like you would have no chance against a combat-trained
484     Orc, let alone four of them.
485     It would help if you'd insert the handle into the winch mechanism.
486     Are you trying to board the helicopter?
487     If of the Orcs you wish to be rid,
487     First you must find where the letter is hid.
487     As time goes by you're sure to find
487     What Bogey once had on his mind.
488     From somewhere in the distance comes the deep throbbing of a heavy
488     engine.
489     The sound of the engine ceases.
490     I'm no engineer, but judging by the sound, the pump engines are
490     overheating.
491     The pumps have run too long without cooling off!  From deep within
491     the mine the engine's throbbing becomes a loud vibrating roar as
491     the great engine tears itself apart.  All around you timbers are
491     cracking!  The entire roof of the mine is collapsing!
492     According to the pump sensors, the mine floor is dry.  Nothing
492     happens.
493     The bank of the ravine is so steep you'll need both hands to climb
493     out.  You can't carry anything.
494     The ravine's north bank is too steep to climb.
495     The ravine is full of water and too wide to swim.
496     The mine entrance has collapsed.  There is no way to enter.
497     The tunnel is completely flooded.  You can't proceed.
498     Opening the cabinet reveals a narrow vertical dumbwaiter shaft.
498     A pulley-mounted chain controls the movement of the dumbwaiter.
499     There isn't any way to climb down the dumbwaiter shaft.
500     The meter reads zero.
501     The meter reads "1".
502     The meter reads "2".
503     The meter reads "3".
504     The meter reads "4".
505     The meter reads "5".
506     The engine is already in operation.
507     The room lights are already on.
508     The room lights were already off.
509     The tunnel is a real squeaker.  You'll be lucky to get through
509     with your clothes on, let alone anything else.
510     The dumbwaiter slides smoothly into view.
511     The dumbwaiter slides smoothly out of sight.
512     Achoo!  Ker-snuf!  I think the dust around this place is
512     getting to me.  Why don't you clean it up a little?
513     You are enveloped in a cloud of noxious-smelling tobacco fumes.
514     The air ahead is filled with huge mosquitos, with stingers the
514     size of icepicks!  The mosquitos haven't yet caught your scent.
514     Do you really want to proceed?
515     Once the mosquitos catch your scent, it's all over very quickly.
515     Sheesh!  You have more holes in you than a pincushion!
516     Your pipe fumes have effectively fumigated your flying foes.  The
516     bothersome bugs beat it as you approach.
517     After playing the flute for a few moments, you become aware of
517     stealthy footsteps behind you.
518     You are being followed by a strangely docile giant Devonian rat!
519     A rat as large as a small pony seems to appear from nowhere.  It seems
519     entranced by the sound of your flute.
520     The big rat, entranced by the music, blindly lurches over the edge
520     of the cliff, only to be pounded to smithereens on the rocks below.
521     The dirty rat is too quick for you!  She easily dodges the blow.
522     Your foolhardy action has broken the spell of the music.  With a
522     lightning-quick move, the mammoth mouse bites you on the forearm
522     with her razor-sharp teeth, and is gone in a flash.
523     The rat bite on your arm, though not deep, is aching.
524     Your arm is aching badly.
525     The dirty rat's wound is festering badly.  The injury may be more
525     serious than you had thought.
526     Your whole arm is infected and turning black.  And the rest of you
526     doesn't feel so hot, either.
527     You are running a very high fever.  Your arm is black and swollen
527     and is hanging by a thread.   You're sinking fast.
